title: King Clancy Memorial Trophy
data: Supporter of numerous charities in Toronto and Calgary
Worked with numerous charities , including the Special Olympics , the Long Island Just Say No to Drugs program , and the Make-A-Wish Foundation
Although very busy as a player and with the NHLPA , he was made the honorary Chairman of the Edmonton City Christmas Bureau , a charity which fed needy persons
Did a lot of charity work with his team , and also assisted persons with speech impediments , as he had previously overcome one
Involved in numerous charities ; he was most notably the honourable Chairman for Boston 's Floating Hospital for Infants and Children
Spent a lot of time helping charities ; he was Co-Chairman of the March of Dimes Walk for Life fundraiser

Was previously recognized by his team and city for his extensive community work . He most notably served as Celebrity Chairman of New York 's Family Dynamic program , a charity which assists abused children
Was the captain of the Flames , and was leader in most of the Flames ' charitable and humanitarian efforts
Was the Jets ' captain as well as a major participant in various charitable organizations
Started a program called the Captain 's Crew , which allowed underprivileged children to attend games in a private suite as his guest
Heavily involved with the Gateway Project , which helped mentally challenged children get involved in various sports
Involved with many charities , including the March of Dimes , the Make-a-Wish Foundation , Walk America and the Roswell Cancer Institute and Children 's hospital

Worked mainly with sick children ; he started Cujo 's Kids , which placed children with illnesses in a luxury suite at a Leafs game ; also created Cujo 's Crease , a special room in the Sick Kids Hospital in Toronto which resembled the Leafs ' dressing room
Founded the Shjon Podein Children 's Foundation , which assists sick and underprivileged children
Involved in a program with Duke Children 's Hospital in Durham , North Carolina that helps children
Started a program that assists with the purchase and installation of smoke detectors for low-income households
Involved in all of the Flames ' community programs , and donated 1,000 dollars for every goal he scored
Co-founded Athletes against Autism after discovering that his son , Carson , had autism ; also involved with numerous other charities
After recovering from cancer , he founded the Saku Koivu Foundation in 2002 , which had raised around 2.5 million dollars when Koivu was awarded
section_text: Brendan Shanahan , 2003 winner Jarome Iginla , 2004 winner Shane Doan , 2010 winner Daniel Sedin ( front ) and Henrik Sedin ( back ) , both 2018 winners ; Henrik is also the 2016 winner , and is the only player to have won more than once . Player is still active
intro: The King Clancy Memorial Trophy is a sports award given annually to the National Hockey League (NHL) player who best exemplifies leadership qualities on and off the ice and who has made a significant humanitarian contribution to his community. The winner is chosen by a special panel of representatives from the Professional Hockey Writers' Association and the NHL Broadcasters' Association. The trophy is named in honour of Francis M. King Clancy, a former player for the Ottawa Senators and Toronto Maple Leafs who later went on to become a coach, referee, and team executive. The trophy was first awarded in 1988 and was presented to the NHL by Maple Leafs owner Harold Ballard, who called Clancy one of the greatest humanitarians that ever lived. It honours similar community service as the Charlie Conacher Humanitarian Award, which was retired in 1984. Five teams have had more than one player win the award. Three members of the Vancouver Canucks, Edmonton Oilers, Calgary Flames, and Boston Bruins have each won the award, with Ray Bourque and Dave Poulin winning the award in consecutive years for the same team for the only time in the history of the award. Two New York Islanders and Detroit Red Wings have also won the award. Players from the seven different Canadian teams have won the trophy on 12 of the 28 occasions that it has been awarded. Three members each from the Edmonton Oilers, Calgary Flames, and Vancouver Canucks, as well as one each from the Montreal Canadiens, Minnesota Wild, Ottawa Senators, Toronto Maple Leafs, and the Winnipeg Jets have each won the award. Henrik Sedin is the only player who has won it more than once. Henrik and his brother Daniel are the only recipients to have won the trophy jointly.
